author: Evan Grant
title: Rangers offseason issue No. 4: Is Jon Daniels interested in a role change?
text:
The Rangers may have had a hard time sleeping after their season came to an abrupt end Wednesday afternoon, but regardless, it's time to put 2015 to bed.
And it's time to start focusing on 2016, because, well, the business of baseball never ends.
With that in mind, here is the fourth of five major issues the Rangers will spend a significant amount of time trying to solve this winter:
In overhauling the bullpen, acquiring Hamels and picking up one late-season contributor after another for absolutely nothing (think Napoli, Will Venable, Wilson, Drew Stubbs), the Rangers' front office did perhaps its best work since 2007.
The biggest reason for this: It was factionless.
There was no "Nolan Ryan faction." Perhaps more significantly, there was no "A.J. Preller/Don Welke faction." There was no lobbying behind the scenes. The group worked more in concert than it had. The additions of Michael Young and Darren Oliver to provide insights into players' minds and the willingness to hear those opinions were important.
Daniels and assistant Thad Levine have worked hard to create an inclusive environment in which scouts, administrators and department heads all feel engaged and invested. The results were evident in how well the Rangers adjusted to changing situations as the season evolved.
Daniels just finished a decade on the job as GM. It is a stress-laden job. Levine, his first hire, has been loyal to the boss and the organization. There is opportunity this fall to start creating a rather seamless line of succession that would allow Levine to ease into the day-to-day role of a GM when Daniels is comfortable with running the organization from the perspective of a president/CEO.
